lines.text:
[takes a bill with Wyatt's signature from a customer and throws it on the faro table]
Wyatt Earp, huh? I heard of you.
Listen, Mr. Kansas Law Dog. Law don't go around here. Savvy?
I'm retired.
Good. That's real good.
Yeah, that's good, Mr. Law Dog, 'cause law don't go around here.
I heard you the first time.
[flips a card]
Winner to the King, five hundred dollars.
Shut up, Ike.

[Ringo steps up to Doc]
And you must be Doc Holliday.
That's the rumor.
You retired too?
Not me. I'm in my prime.
Yeah, you look it.
And you must be Ringo. Look, darling, Johnny Ringo. The deadliest pistoleer since Wild Bill, they say. What do you think, darling? Should I hate him?
You don't even know him.
Yes, but there's just something about him. Something around the eyes, I don't know, reminds me of... me. No. I'm sure of it, I hate him.

[to Ringo]
He's drunk.
In vino veritas.
"When I'm drinking, I speak my mind"]
Age quod agis.
"Do what you do best"]
Credat Judaeus apella, non ego.
"I don't believe drinking is what I do best."]

[pats his gun]
Eventus stultorum magister.
"Fools have to learn by experience"]

[gives a Cheshire cat smile]
In pace requiescat.
"It's your funeral!"]
Come on boys. We don't want any trouble in here. Not in any language.
Evidently Mr. Ringo's an educated man. Now I really hate him.
I'm your huckleberry...
All right, Clanton... you called down the thunder, well now you've got it! You see that?
[pulls open his coat, revealing a badge]
It says United States Marshal!

[terrified, pleading]
Wyatt, please, I...

[referring to Stilwell, laying dead]
Take a good look at him, Ike... 'cause that's how you're gonna end up!
[shoves Ike down roughly with his boot]
The Cowboys are finished, you understand? I see a red sash, I kill the man wearin' it!
[lets Ike up to run for his life]
So run, you cur... RUN! Tell all the other curs the law's comin'!
[shouts]
You tell 'em I'M coming... and hell's coming with me, you hear?...
[louder]
Hell's coming with me!

[to Johnny Ringo]
Why Johnny Ringo, you look like somebody just walked over your grave.
What is that now? Twelve hands in a row? Holliday, son of a bitch, nobody's that lucky.
Why Ike, whatever do you mean? Maybe poker's just not your game Ike. I know! Let's have a spelling contest!
Why, it's the drunk piano player. You're so drunk, you can't hit nothin'. In fact, you're probably seeing double.
[Billy Clanton draws a knife]

[takes out a second gun]
I have two guns, one for each of ya.
Doc, you oughta be in bed, what the hell you doin this for anyway?
Wyatt Earp is my friend.
Hell, I got lots of friends.
I don't.
My fight's not with you, Holliday.
I beg to differ, sir. We started a game we never got to finish. "Play for Blood," remember?
Oh that. I was just foolin' about.
I wasn't.

[to Johnny Ringo, after shooting him in a duel]
You're no daisy! You're no daisy at all. Poor soul, you were just too high strung.
Oh. Johnny, I apologize; I forgot you were there. You may go now.
Where is he?
Down by the creek, walking on water.
What makes a man like Ringo, Doc? What makes him do the things he does?
A man like Ringo has got a great big hole, right in the middle of him. He can never kill enough, or steal enough, or inflict enough pain to ever fill it.
What does he need?
Revenge.
For what?
Bein' born.

[taunting a card player who believes Holliday is cheating him]
Why Ed does this mean we're not friends anymore? You know Ed, if I thought you weren't my friend... I just don't think I could bear it!
Nonsense, I have not yet begun to defile myself.

[as Doc Holliday is drunkenly playing a somber piece on the saloon piano, Clanton speaks, just as drunkenly]
Is that "Old Dog Trey? Sounds like "Old Dog Trey."
Pardon?
Stephen Foster. "Oh, Susannah", "Camptown Races". Stephen stinking Foster.
Ah, yes. Well, this happens to be a nocturne.
A which?
You know, Frederic fucking Chopin.
Nobody move!
Nonsense. By all means, move.
Hey Johnny, what did that Mexican mean by a sick horse is going to get us?
He was quoting the Bible, Revelations. "Behold the pale horse". The man who "sat on him was Death... and Hell followed with him".

[Tyler reaches for his gun]
Go ahead, skin it! Skin that smokewagon and see what happens...

[pauses, scared]
M-mister, I'm gettin' tired of your...

[slaps Tyler across the face, unafraid]
I'm gettin' tired of all your gas, now jerk that pistol and go to work!

[slaps him harder, now completely steely-eyed]
I said throw down, boy!
My hypocrisy goes only so far.
It's true, you are a good woman. Then again, you may be the antichrist.
What did you ever want?
Just to live a normal life.
There's no normal life, Wyatt, it's just life. Get on with it.
Don't know how.

Sure you do. Say goodbye to me. Go grab that spirited actress and make her your own. Take that beauty from it, don't look back. Live every second. Live right on to the end. Live Wyatt. Live for me. Wyatt, if you were ever my friend - if ya ever had even the slightest of feelin' for me, leave now. Leave now... Please.
Thanks for always being there, Doc.

[waiting by an oak tree for Wyatt Earp for a showdown, he believes the person approaching is Wyatt]
Well,I didn't think ya had it in you.
I'm your huckleberry.
[Ringo is startled that it's Holliday and not Wyatt]
Why, Johnny Ringo, you look like somebody just walked over your grave.
Fight's not with you, Holliday.
I'll beg to differ, sir. We started a game we never got to finish. Play for blood, remember?
I was just foolin' about.
I wasn't. And this time...
[opens his coat to reveal a U.S. Deputy Marshal Badge]
... it's legal.
All right, lunger. Let's do it.

[they both start moving in circles slowly into position for a showdown, staring at each other without blinking]
Say when.

[they both draw but Holliday is a tad quicker and shoots Ringo in the head and Ringo struggles to stay standing and finally falls]
Poor soul. You were just too high-strung.
[Holliday places the badge on Ringo's corpse]

[Holliday hears running footsteps and turns to see Wyatt Earp approaching]
I'm afraid the strain was more than he could bear. Oh, I wasn't quite as sick as I made out.
Good God.
[knells to examine Ringo and picks up the badge]
My hypocrisy goes only so far.
All right. Let's finish it.
Indeed, sir. The last charge of Wyatt Earp and his immortals
[Wyatt Earp has just found out that the devil in a play was performed by a woman]
Well, I'll be damned.
You may indeed, if you get lucky.
Make no mistake, it's not revenge he's after. It's a reckonin'.
From now on I see a red sash, I kill the man wearing it. So run you cur. And tell the other curs the law is coming. You tell 'em I'm coming! And Hell's coming with me you hear! Hell's coming with me!
Forgive me if I don't shake hands.

[a mortally wounded McLaury is taking aim at Doc]
I've got you now... you son of a bitch!

[holds up arms]
You're a daisy if you do!
[Morgan shoots McLaury]
I stand corrected, Wyatt. You're an oak.
It appears my hypocrisy knows no bounds.
Doc you're not a hypocrite, you just like to sound like one.
How are you?
I'm dying, how are you?
Sheriff Behan, have you met Doc Holliday?
Piss on you, Wyatt.
Why Johnny Tyler! You madcap!
Doc?
Where you goin' with that shotgun?

[attempting to translate what the Mexican priest said]
He talkin loco... crazy... somethin' about a sick horse comin' to get us.
That's not what he said, you ignorant wretch. Your Spanish is worse than your English.
How many cards do you want?
I don't want to play any more.
How many?
Damn it, you're the most fallible, stubborn, self-deluded, bullheaded man I've ever known in my entire life.
I call.
[looks at Doc's cards]
You win.
You're the only human being in my entire life that ever gave me hope...
You run your mouth awful reckless for a man that don't go heeled.
No need to go heeled to get the bulge on a tub like you.
[last lines]

The Red Sash Cowboy Gang was broken forever. Ike Clanton was shot and killed two years later during an attempted robbery. Mattie died of a drug overdose shortly after she left Tombstone. Virgil and Allie Earp moved to California where Virgil, despite the use of only one arm, became a town sheriff. Wyatt and Josephine embarked on a series of adventures. Up or down, thin or flush, in 47 years they never left each other's side. Wyatt Earp died in Los Angeles in 1929. Among the pallbearers at his funeral, were early western stars William S. Hart and Tom Mix. Tom Mix wept.
Did you ever see anything like that before?
Hell, I ain't never even heard of anything like that.
Why Kate, you're not wearing a bustle. How lewd.
You gonna do somethin'? Or are you just gonna stand there and bleed?

[Stillwell and Ike are planning to ambush the Earps at the train station]
That's Virgil there with the women.
He's mine, understand?

[Cocking his rifle]
Hey Mattie! Where's Wyatt?
Right behind you, Stillwell.
[Shoots Stillwell as he turns around]

[after killing Johnny Ringo]
It would appear that the strain was more than he could bear.
Fight's commenced! Get to fightin' or get away!
[while watching a play in which Faust sells his soul to the Devil]
You know what I'd do? I'd take that deal 'n' crawfish, then drill that ol' Devil in the ass. What about you Juanito, what would you do?
I already did it.

[to Ike Clanton]
You die first, get it? Your friends might get me in a rush, but not before I make your head into a canoe, you understand me?

[Ringo has taken Holliday up on his offer to 'finish the game']
All right, 'lunger'. Let's do it.
Say when.
What the hell kinda town is this?
Nice scenery.
Well, an enchanted moment.
Interesting little scene. I wonder who that tall drink of water is.
My dear, you've set your gaze upon the quintessential frontier type. Note the lean silhouette... eyes closed by the sun, though sharp as a hawk. He's got the look of both predator and prey.
I want one.
Happy hunting.
[Morgan is fatally wounded in a gunfight]
Remember what I said about people seein' a bright light before they die? It ain't true. I can't see a damn thing.
Very cosmopolitan.
What's wrong with him?
[asking about Doc]
Lunger.
Yeah, well I hope you die.
[speaking to Doc]
I don't think I'll let you arrest us today, Behan.

[to the Cowboys, who have just shot him in the knee]
You go hell!
You first.
[shoots]
You skin that smoke wagon and we'll see what happens!
Listen mister, I'm getting awful tired of your...
[Wyatt slaps him]
Are you gonna do something? Or just stand there and bleed?
How we feelin' today, Doc?
I'm dying. How are you?
Pretty much the same.
I'm a woman, I like men. If that means I'm not "lady-like", then I guess I'm just not a lady! At least I'm honest.
You're different. No arguin' that. But you're a lady alright. I'd take my oath on it.
I want your blood. And I want your souls. And I want them both right now!
I did my duty, now I'd like to get on with my life. I'm going to Tombstone.
Ah, I see. To strike it rich. Well, all right, that's fine. Tell you one thing, though... I never saw a rich man who didn't wind up with a guilty conscience.
Already got a guilty conscience. Might as well have the money, too. Good day, now.
And so she walked out of our lives forever.

In all that time workin' those cow towns, I was only ever mixed up in one shootin', just one! But a man lost his life and I took it! You don't know how that feels, and believe me boy, you don't ever want to know. Not ever!
[first lines]

1879 - the Civil War is over, and the resulting economic explosion spurs the great migration west. Farmers, ranchers, prospectors, killers, and thieves seek their fortune. Cattle growers turn cow towns into armed camps, with murder rates higher than than those of modern day New York or Los Angeles. Out of this chaos comes legendary lawman Wyatt Earp, retiring his badge and gun to start a peaceful life for his family. Earp's friend, John, Doc Holliday, a southern gentlemen turned gunman and gambler, also travels west, hoping the dry climate would relieve his tuberculosis. Silver is discovered in Arizona. Tombstone becomes queen of the boom towns where the latest Pairs fashions are sold from the backs of wagons. Attracted to this atmosphere of greed, over 100 exiled Texas outlaws band together to form the ruthless gang recognized by the red sashes they wear. They emerge as the earliest example of organized crime in America. They call themselves, The Cowboys.
It said that a lot of people, when they die, they see this light. Like in a tunnel. They say it's the light leadin' you to heaven.
Really? Well, what about hell? They got a sign there or what?

[Before the shootout at the OK Corral]
"It's not your problem, Doc, you don't have to mix up in this."

[Offeneded]
"That is a hell of a thing for you to say to me."
You must be Ringo.
[to Big Nose Kate]
Look, darlin', it's Johnny Ringo. Deadliest pistoleer since Wild Bill, they say. What do you think, darlin', should I hate him?
I just want you to know it's over between us.
Well... bye.
Smell that, Bill? Smells like someone died.
I spent my whole life not knowing what I want out of it, just chasing my tail. Now for the first time I know exactly what I want and who... that's the damnable misery of it.
You could have been busted up back there, or killed.
Fun, though, wasn't it?
You'd die for fun?
Wouldn't you?

[Ringo is trying to get McMasters to rejoin the Cowboys]
So, there's nothin' I can say to get you to come back?
Not after what you done. Not after shootin' at the Earp's women.
All right then, I guess you can just get back on your horse and ride back down there to your new friends.

[placing a shotgun to McMaster's head]
Hey. I just got one question; how're you planning on gettin' back down there?

[about Wyatt]
If they were my brothers, I'd want revenge, too.
Oh, make no mistake. It's not revenge he's after. It's a reckoning.
Look at all the stars. You look up and you think, "God made all this and He remembered to make a little speck like me." It's kind of flattering, really.
I've been good to you, I've taken care of you. If you die, where does that leave me?
Without a meal ticket I suppose.
[Doc rides horse out of barn into stable area, Kate runs out after him punching him in anger]
You bastard!
Why Kate, have you no kind words for me as I ride away?
[pause]
I calculate not.
[rides off]
Sheriff, allow me to present a pair of fellow sophisticates. Turkey Creek Jack Johnson and Texas Jack Vermillion. Mind your ear, Creek.
You're the only person I can afford to loose to any more. How we feelin' today doc?
I'm dyin', how are you?
Pretty much the same.
You are all under arrest.
I don't think I'm going to allow you to arrest us today, Behan.
Weave a circle round him thrice, / And close your eyes with holy dread, / For he on honey-dew hath fed, / And drunk the milk of Paradise.
Wearing that badge don't make you right.
You gonna stick with your new friends?
'Least they don't go around scarin' women.

[to Josephine Marcus]
I have nothing left, nothing to give you, I have no pride, no dignity, no money, I don't even know how we'll make a living, but I promise I'll love you the rest of your life
[they kiss]

[Vigil has agreed to become Tombstone's town marshall, upsetting Wyatt]
What in the hell are you doin'? I told you we weren't gettin' involved!
You got us involved when you brought us here.
Now you hold on a minute, Virg!

Hold on nothin'! I walk around this town and look these people in the eyes. It's just like someone's slappin' me in the face! These people are afraid to walk down the street, and I'm tryin' to make money off that like some goddamn vulture! If we're gonna have a future in this town, it's gotta have some law and order!
Don't do this to me!
It's got nothin' to do with you! It's got to do wi...
Nothin' to do with me? I'm your brother, for Christ's sake! God, I don't believe this!
[to Morgan]
Talk to him, will you? Or hit him!
[Morgan sheepishly shows Wyatt his deputy badge under his coat]
Ah, God, don't tell me!
Like you said, Wyatt, we're brothers. Gotta back your brother's play. Just did like I figured you would.

Okay, fine. Say you're right, say you don't get yourself killed. There's somethin' else. All those years I worked those cow towns, I was only ever mixed up in one shootin', just one. But a man lost his life, and I took it. You don't know how that feels, Morg. Believe me, boy, you don't ever wanna know. Not ever.
Tonight, me and my old man are gonna have some fun. Come on, get movin', old man.

[to the rest of the Earps, as his wife takes him away]
Maiden name was Sullivan.
Christ Almighty, it's like I'm sittin' here playin' cards with my brother's kids or somethin'. You nerve-wrackin' sons-a-bitches.

[after a vicious gunfight with the Mexican police]
Looks like we win.
let's have a spelling contest.
How the hell did we get ourselves into this?
We're growing. Be as big as San Francisco in a few years, and just as sophisticated.
